Datatable.LocalizationPair: The Kapaku have had a troubled past with planets. After their first one was terraformed into a disgusting lush forest, and their second one froze over, the Kapaku decided to find their own, perfect, planet.
The Kapaku are strange race, with the unique ability to use geomancy, and a love for volcanic terrain.
The assimilation of the Kapaku leads to a similar disposition to Hot planets as the Kapaku themselves, which is one of awe and optimism.
The Kapaku have had Terraforming technology for much longer than most other races, and therefore, understand how to apply it more efficiently.
The Broken Lords in an emergency coalition of other factions, not to be outdone by the Vaulters, cooperated to develop spacecraft to escape Auriga.
Once a proud nation of chivalrous knights, now crippled with a curse that traps their spirit within their armor. They have yet to break their curse, but have lost their motivation to do so.
Using the vampiric power of the Broken Lords, but combined with safer methods, you can passively extract non-lethal amounts of dust from citizens.
Using the restorative power of dust that the Broken Lords have come to learn, you can make all slowly repair themselves.

Slowly escaping Auriga via sneakily stowing away on Exploration Vessels in generous numbers, the Forgotten eventually decided to start anew and dispersed throughout the galaxy. Eventually though they become disgusted at how similarly they were treated in these new lands that they decided to congregate and form their own nation once again.
Rogues and spies with a unique ability to turn invisible at will, the Forgotten use dirty tricks and thievery to get what they want.
The Forgotten have a truly amazing tactic for making pilots fly their ships faster: Threathen them.
Having an expertise in infiltration and spying has its perks, and making the Forgotten gunners makes weaponry more likely to hit.

Realizing that their quest to save the planet was futile, the Drakken, through a massive civil conflict and change of leadership, decided that the only thing they could do was organize a collected effort off of the planet.
The Drakken resemble the great dragons of fantasy. However, contrary to their fantasy counterparts, the Drakken prefer a much more diplomatic approach to conflict.
The Drakken are skilled at diplomacy, giving them the ability to swiftly and efficiently declare diplomatic declarations.
Using their unnatural prowess at speechcraft, the Drakken are able to rile the people up in resisting the cultural takeover of other empires.
The Morgawr have always been confined to the waters, and to Auriga... But now, Morgawr are free, free to embrace their curious nature.
The Morgawr, experiments of the Endless, resemble mutated fish. They crave Freedom over everything else, and prefer Ocean planets.
Using their manipulation of lesser minds for social engineering, the Morgawr can vastly improve your societal structure.
The Morgawr's affinity for water rubs off on your other citizens, vastly improving production on Fertile planets.
Once stranded on the dying Auriga, the Wild Walkers turned to the stars in a last ditch effort, using any resources they had left to escape with the remaining Vaulters.
Once mere hunter-gatherers, they have an uncanny ability to shape rocks and trees into great buildings, and an unnatural bond to animals.
Using their affinity to nature, the Wild Walkers can replace the need for materials such as Steel or Titanium with naturally growing and regenerative substances, greatly decreasing production costs.

Finding their exceptional natural connection to beasts still applies off of Auriga, the Wild Walkers use their understanding bond to animals create a wide web of sight, greatly enchancing detection range.
Unsettled by the mysteries of the Galaxy, the Clans focused more on internal infrastructure and economics, becoming masters at each with ease.
No longer simple nomadic traders, explorers, and adventurers, the Clans have since modernized into something more professional.
Using their natural understanding of economics, the Roving Clans can pinpoint miniscule inefficiencies in system economies, squashing a major percentage of costs.
Treating the military like a business, the Clans can repurpose, organize, and trim their way to perfect efficiency.

A single, vast plantlike organism that manipulates its many children, even from afar. Since ancient times, they have had a symbiotic relationship with the Urkans, and even managed to save one from Auriga's frost.
Ancient dwellers of a subterranean realm lost to Auriga, the Mykara, being made of plants themselves, have a special gift at agriculture.
Having an intimate understanding of Anatomy and Biology, the Mykara can make eating as efficient as possible by creating enhanced foods.
By growing plant-based soldiers, you can have a near infinite amount of soldiers for little to no cost.

The largest of the three great beasts, Kazar moves with an unhurried gait that belies its great strength and arrogance. Often crusted with precious ores when emerging from the depths, Kazar is sometimes the target of brave, or foolhardy, adventures who attempt to liberate the valuable stones.
The Cultists of the Eternal End are led by The Queen and the Unspoken and will go to all ends to ensure that its will is carried out through the conversion of lesser groups.
Vigilant and hyperproductive in all aspects, with an unwavering support for the queen, the Cultists make excellent citizens as long as you don't let too many of them go in the same space.
Pouring their heart and faith into masterwork ship plating, your ships gain a large boost in durability.
A single, massive sanctum is built on every planet in your empire, serving as a center for mass-housing, but also a center of worship to the Cultists.

One of the original races of Auriga, the Allayi struggled greatly with their exodus from the planet. Once intrinsically linked to the planet, they have adapted to feel a similar bond to any planet they reside on.
With a unique ability to phase between different forms, the Allayi are adaptable and ferocious when threatened.
Close-knight and loyal, the strategically located Allayi can have a tremendous effect on loyalty when taking solar systems.
Though Auriga is gone, she left one final gift to the Allayi that they pass onto you.
